Ungratefull times that impiously neglect</br>That worth that never times againe shall shew,</br>What, merites all our toile no more respect?</br>Or else standes idlenes asham'd to know</br>Those wondrous Actions that do so object</br>Blame to the wanton, sin unto the slow?</br>Can England see the best that shee can boast</br>Ly thus ungrac'd, undeckt, and almost lost?

Why do you seeke for fained Palladins</br>Out of the smoke of idle vanitie,</br>That maie give glorie to the true dissignes</br>Of Bourchier, Talbot, Nevile, Willoughby?</br>Why should not you straive to fill up your lines</br>With wonders of your owne, with veritie?</br>T'Inflame their offspring with the love of Good</br>And glorious true examples of their blood.

O what eternall matter here is found!</br>Whence new immortal Iliads do abound</br>In blessed accents here maie have to feed</br>Good thoughts, on no imaginary ground</br>Of hungrie shadowes which no profit breed:</br>Whence musicke like, instant delight may grow,</br>But when men all do know they nothing know.

And why dost thou in lamentable verse</br>Nothing but bloudshed, treasons, sin and shame,</br>The worst of times, th' extreame of ils rehearse,</br>To raise old staines, and to renew dead blame?</br>As if the minds of th' evill, and perverse</br>Were not far sooner trained from the fame</br>By good example of faire vertuous acts,</br>Then by the shew of foule ungodly facts.

O that our times had some sacred wight,</br>Whose wordes as happie as our swordes had bin</br>To have prepared for us Trophies aright</br>Of undecaying frames t' have rested in:</br>Triumphant Arkes of perdurable might</br>O holy lines:  that such advauntage win</br>Upon the Sieth of time in spight of yeares,</br>How blessed they that gaine what never weares.</br>
